question.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>60</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of ice at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> is added to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>200</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of water initially at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>70</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> in a calorimeter of unknown water equivalent <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>W</mi></math>. If the final temperature of the mixture is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>40</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>, then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>W</mi></math> is [Take latent heat of fusion of ice <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn><mo> </mo><mi>cal</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> and specific heat capacity of water <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi>cal</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>]

solution.text:
The principle of calorimetry states that for an isolated system,

The heat gained by the cold body (Here it is ice) = The heat lost by the hot body (Here it is water + calorimeter)

miceLf+mices∆T=mwater+Ws∆T

⇒60×80+60×1×40=200+W×1×30

⇒480+240=600+3W

⇒W=40 g
